This existence of domains and their motion in  $\mathbf{B}_0$  are not speculations.

One may observe this under a microscope after sprinkling a liquid suspension of powdered ferromagnetic substance of samples.

This motion of suspension can be observed.

Fig.

5.8(b) shows the situation when the domains have aligned and amalgamated to form a single 'giant' domain.
summary: Small clusters, called domains, in ferromagnetic sets that have aligned their magnetic moments with an external field, are vulnerable and follow the field lines when it is turned off.
hypothetical_questions: Attracted by what force in the external field will the domains align when turned off?
What is the most prominent phenomenon to observe during this experiment?
What temperature increases the domain's magnetic susceptibility?
